poem:
Golden Chatter

Golden rule of chat—  
they speak, and seas part.  
Whispers between the lines,  
letters penned in paths  
unseen.  
Hearts that fall  
into crafted lines,  
strange love in ink.  
To speak, to hush,  
a dance of tongues  
behind gilded curtains—  
words like seeds  
scattered on this  
wind-whipped stage.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The golden rule of Trump and Farage’s free speech crusade: they’re allowed to chat rubbish – you’re not | Marina Hyde Pop quiz. Of whom did Donald Trump say admiringly: “I also learned that he loves his country very much”? And: “He wrote me beautiful letters. And they are great letters. We fell in love”? If you answered “Nigel Farage”, then I’m sorry. The Reform UK leader might have spent this pre-party conference week in". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
